captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

MIKE MUSTO: Things
that are orange--

pumpkins, cats, Doritos,
lollipops, orange sherbet,

cheese, orange juice, carrots,
tulips, tigers--
rrr--

orioles, Monarch butterflies,
and sunburned Irish people--
and the 1959 Pontiac Bonneville
that sits behind me.

Welcome to a very big, big
episode of "BIG MUSCLE."
My name is Mike Musto.

Each week I travel the country
with the goal of showcasing

the best and baddest muscle
cars and hot rods around.

Every car has a past, and
every owner, a story.

Welcome to the world
of "BIG MUSCLE."
[MUSIC PLAYING]

MIKE MUSTO: Over the past three
seasons of "BIG MUSCLE,"

we've shown you a wide variety
of cars from a host of
different time periods.

However, if we were to pick one
that was guided by sheer

wonder and forward thinking,
it would have to
be that of the 1950s.

This was a time when ornate
designs and artistic freedom

defined American
transportation.

Automobiles had interiors that
looked like opera houses,

fenders that made you stare, and
faces as different as the
people who bought them.

Today's market, on other hand,
demands a relatable

individuality, which explains
why there are so many

four-door coupes on the road and
why everyone's headlights
look so damn angry.

This is the 1959 Pontiac
Bonneville.

The interior is a jewelry box,
the exterior, a perfect blend

of intricate creases
and smooth folds.
This car is about design.

So guys, let's start
by saying this.

This is not a road
burner of a car.
It is not a tire smoker.
It is not a drift car.
It is not a canyon carver.

And it's not something that you
sit in and do donuts with.

Therefore, you might be asking
yourself, well, why is it on
"BIG MUSCLE"?
And the reason is simple--
look at it.

One of the best-looking
cars that I've seen in
a long, long time.

When we first met Chuck, I asked
him flat out, I go, what

is going on with this
orange paint?

The fact that he said it was
Lamborghini orange, the car

was on RideTech's airbag
suspension, you know, you
start to think of things.

And he did have somewhat of a
vision with this car, and he

pulled it off absolutely
beautifully.

You have to get past the fact
that it's not a 500 or

600-horsepower car and
look at the details.

You have to look at the
dashboard and look at how

everything is aircraft
inspired.

You got to remember,
this was 1959.
This was the jet age.

So everything is kind of
airplane related, right?

You've got these beautiful
toggle switches that you flip

down for your temperature,
your heat, and what not.

Push buttons for the controls,
not fancy or ornate.
Ah, they work.
That's even better.

All right, so let me ask you a
question, I mean, why a '59
Bonneville?
CHUCK CUSHNER: Why not?
It's a beautiful style.

I love the mid to
late '50s cars.

The '59 Bonneville was the
first of the wide body.
It was an extra-long car.

It was just a beautiful
car from the factory.

And I was never able to afford
one when they were new or even
within a few years of that.

So I saw this one for sale and
thought I'd go for it.

The car had been sitting in
Kansas in someone's backyard
for probably about 15 years.

They had tried to customize it,
again, probably about 15
years before, got tired of it.

It was sitting in the
backyard, but it was
basically all there.

I was able to get it at
a reasonable price.
I saw pictures of it.
So I had them ship it out.

It was in decent condition
for a car that's
sitting in a field.

I mean, there were rats living
in it, and there was some body

rot, but there was definitely
a lot of potential.

And as I was telling you
earlier, that when the flatbed

came up and this thing was on
the back of the flatbed, my

wife came out, and she
was ready to call the
psychiatrist.

I was definitely gone
over the edge.
But I said I have a vision.

MIKE MUSTO: Now, was
that truth or--

CHUCK CUSHNER: Well, I always
tell her I have a vision
anytime I want to do anything.

I never go into anything
blindly, right?

It may be stupid at the time,
maybe even afterwards.

But I thought it was
the right decision.

MIKE MUSTO: For '59, it was
Pontiac's first year of the

quote, unquote "wide-track"
stance, which means the wheels

on the car on the front and back
were actually moved to
the outer corners.

This helped the car get
a much more stable
ride, which it does.
This car rides beautifully.

And they used the whole
wide-track thing for about 10

years or so, then
they dropped it.

Then the mid to late '80s hit,
and it was Pontiac wide-track
all over again.

It was more of a marketing
thing.

But if you look at the body
itself, this is a massive,
massive car.
This car is 19-feet-long.

The rear quarter panel stretches
from the back of my

door-- obviously, it's
not a surprise.

But to the end, the rear
quarter panel is
almost 8 feet long.
That's one panel.

Think about the stamping process
that the manufacturers
had to go through for that.

Think about how big the
deck lid, right?

We open that trunk, you can
almost fit-- and I'm not
exaggerating--

a full-sized mattress in
the trunk laid down.

In fact, you could
fit the entire--

let's see, we could probably
fit nine Chris Harris', OK?

I'm going to go with
13 Leo Parentes.
We can do maybe seven JFs.

In short, the entire DRIVE team
could go on holiday in
the trunk of this car.
It's just obscenely huge.

Power-wise, you step on the gas
in this thing, and it's
got more than enough grunt.

CHUCK CUSHNER: It's got plenty
of power for me.

MIKE MUSTO: But the motor's
original to the car, correct?

CHUCK CUSHNER: Yeah,
the running
gear is 100% original--

the engine, transmission,
rear end.

And I haven't changed anything
mechanically on the car.

MIKE MUSTO: And how
big is the engine?

CHUCK CUSHNER: It's a 289 cubic
engine, 300 horsepower.

MIKE MUSTO: And the car's
got to weigh what?
4,800 pounds?

CHUCK CUSHNER: It's about
4,800 pounds, so
it's a lot of weight.

You do need a big engine, but
it's plenty powerful enough.

These cars did come with three
2s also, which brought the
horsepower up.

But this car when I found it
had the four barrel, and I
loved it that way.
MIKE MUSTO: The Bonneville--

I think you were saying
before, this
shares the same basic--

I guess it's the glass and the
roof line with a couple of
other cars, no?
CHUCK CUSHNER: Right.

I guess it's called the roof
line or the belt line up.

It's the same exact as the 1959
Chevy, 1959 Cadillac, and
the Pontiac.

So '59 and '60 are
exactly the same.

So the windows, everything about
it is exactly the same.

MIKE MUSTO: The '59 Bonneville,
though, this

design, with the tail lamps and
the split fin, this was
'59 only though, correct?
CHUCK CUSHNER: Correct.

So the body itself from the
side windows down is 1959
Pontiac only.

So this has four fins
in the back.
That's '59 only.

The split grill in the front,
this was the first year of the

split Pontiac grill, but in
'60 they did away with it.

So when you see a car with the
four fins in the back and the

split grill in the front and
almost 19 feet long, you know
that it's a '59 Pontiac.

MIKE MUSTO: One of the cool
parts about this particular
car is the rear-view mirrors.

The rear-view mirror is just
this beautiful little stalk,

adjustable, but it's very
nicely sculpted.

Now for your side-view mirror,
which the car only has one,

it's not mounted traditionally
on the door, which most cars
obviously have.

It's actually mounted up here
on the front fender.

I mean, you could bring that
back today, and it would make
perfect sense.

Manufacturers, they lose their
way at times, I think, and

they forget about
what design is.

And I can guess we know times
have changed, and we know
modern elements come into it.

And there are things like safety
features and whatnot,

and all the technology that
they want to put, so parts
become bigger and bulkier.

But I don't understand why you
still can't design something
that's beautiful.
I mean, think about it.

When was the last time you saw
a really beautiful car?

Aside from something super
exotic, like a Ferrari or a

Lamborghini, when was the last
time you saw a beautiful car

that made you stop and
go, oh my god.

A car like this that makes you
just want to look inside of it

and under it and look at the
gauges and the switches and

stuff, the chrome
work on the car.

The fact that Bonneville
is actually raised
off the dash in script.

The fact that the bezels have
the fins of a starship on

them, and that your gauges are
so unbelievably clear, that
why can't you do that again?

The fact that we have these
little quarter windows that

are-- oops, that's the real
window-- little quarter

windows that are cranks,
and they crank open.
I love it.
I love it.
I love it.

You people say, well, what do
you think about modern cars?
I think they're appliances.

They have some semblance of
use, and we all know that.

But man, for style, you can't
touch a car like this.

You simply cannot touch
a car like this.

When I first saw this car, I
felt like I was a kid at the
World's Fair.

I felt like it should be on a
rotisserie, and this should be
a concept car.

It almost doesn't
look real to me.

You look at the ornate dash,
the chrome and the orange

paint, the wire wheels and the
white walls, and then you get

in it and you start it, and
you hear that rumble.
It's not crazy fast.

It doesn't handle like
a slot car, and
it does not do burnouts.

This is a car that's made for
driving, and it was just
outstanding.

Some cars have distinct
personalities.

This one just says look at me,
enjoy me, and don't let me go.

And it's something that
I don't want to do.

So on that note, guys, thanks
for watching "BIG MUSCLE," and
we'll see you again next week.
I love this car.

I actually might go to jail,
because I don't want
to give this back.
You got pulled over here.

THADDEUS BROWN: Was
it right here?

MIKE MUSTO: This is where you
got pulled over in Zack's
Cobra last season.
THADDEUS BROWN: Oh.
MIKE MUSTO: Right here.
THADDEUS BROWN: Right here?
MIKE MUSTO: Uh-huh.

This is where your
hat flew off.
THADDEUS BROWN: Oh.

MIKE MUSTO: Yep, that's
the place.

Thaddeus got busted here last
year when we were filming
Zack's Cobra.

And he was like, I just
want to drive it once.

And you drove it, and you went
from 0 to 85 in about 8

seconds and immediately
got pulled over.

THADDEUS BROWN: I made
it farther than that.
MIKE MUSTO: You did?

THADDEUS BROWN: Much
farther than that.

comments.text: so that's where Pagani got his interior "ideas" hehe.﻿
comments.author: jey lee

comments.text:
Why can't people care about beauty anymore in cars? Concept designs make 
radical designs, but those are not always the best looking. I think cost 
and money come into play A LOT. Companies are cheap nowadays, they know 
you're willing to buy anything with good GAS MILEAGE, ECO FRIENDLY, HYBRID, 
ELECTRIC, ELECTRONICS. Style on the other hand is an afterthought, 
aerodynamics might be more important. 

I have a 1992 Bonneville passed down from my grandfather when he passed 
away. It's a beautiful car, in perfect condition with only 70,000 miles, he 
bought it used from an old lady who barely drove it. After so many year he 
didn't get out anymore so it sat for 12 years. Had to redo the entire fuel 
system and the brakes, but the car works amazingly now, the interior is 
spotless, I only take it out on the weekends, it's stored away for the 
winter. While it's not technically a classic, I like to think it will be 
one day. It was the first year of the newer body style Bonnevilles and 
rides like a dream, very quiet and comfortable. It has power seats, which 
my new 2013 Dart doesn't even have, some stuff just amazes me.  ﻿
comments.author: EqualsThreeable

comments.author: David Smith

comments.text:
+David Smith I don't know where you live, but your statement couldn't be 
more wrong. The average driver in the US drives about 13,000 to 14,000 
miles a year. Depending on age group and gender those figures can change 
dramatically.   Americans do the most driving during middle age and the 
least driving during retirement. Americans between 35 and 54 years of age 
drive 15,291 miles per year on average. This person just drives above 
average, as do I. I drive between 22,000 to 29,000 miles annually.  Even 
back in 1959, the situation was pretty much the same.  You had to drive 
where the work was.
comments.author: itsmegp46

comments.author: DesertDigger1

comments.text:
Besides the nice crank wing windows it should have had the front kick panel 
vents too? Those old cars have great ventilation. I miss that on newer 
cars. My Grandfather had one he drove all over the US, Michigan to Florida 
and to California. It was a road car for sure. I agree great looks gobs of 
chrome everywhere. ﻿
comments.author: Joe Goodart

comments.text:
My favorite aunt bought one of these new in 1959 when I was two years old. 
She drove it for five years (then traded it in for a `64 Bonneville), and I 
can remember riding in it as a kid in the early `60s. The two features I 
most clearly remember:  One, the rear deck window arched upward and 
forward, extending over the heads of the back-seat passengers by a 
half-foot or so.  At night, you could tilt your head back and look upward 
for a view of the stars. And two, the frosty-cold air conditioner -- an 
extremely rare luxury option in those days. ﻿

comments.text:
+k kirkland A friend of mine had a '69 Mustang with a 427 cubic 
inch stroker small block .lol Big block is determined by the size of the 
crank and cam journal castings,not the cubic inch displacement which is 
bore times stroke.Hudson back in the early 1950s had an inline six cylinder 
that was displaced at 308 cubes,the Olds Rocket V-8 was diplaced at 303 
cubes and had two extra cylinders.
comments.author: Robert LaPointe

comments.text:
+Robert LaPointe
   yep.  i had a 69 ford f700  dump truck and it had a FE big block 331.
comments.author: k kirkland

comments.text:
+McJimbo De-Fundy Cubic inch displacement does not necessarily mean Big 
Block.It should be noted that Ford's first big block had displacement of 
332 and 352 cubic inches yet had small blocks that had 351 and 400 cubic 
inches.Chevrolet's first big block had 348 cubic inches,yet Chevrolet 
produced small blocks with 350 and 400 cubic inches. Samll blocks can have 
large displacement as well.Chevrolet also had a 6.2 liter small block which 
is around 383 cubic inches.The so called 383 stroker is popular among hot 
rodders right now.The 383 is a 327 or 350 piston(BORE) with a 400 stroke 
which is around 3.75. What determines small block and big block is the 
casting size.Mainly the size of the crankshaft and camshaft bearing journal 
diameters.Bore and stroke or cubic inch displacement does not determine if 
its small or big block. You can get as much as 470 cubic inches out of a 
small block Chevrolet.
comments.author: Robert LaPointe

comments.text:
Hell of a car, either way... Does 'large displacement V8' mean 'big-block,' 
in the vernacular?
comments.author: McJimbo De-Fundy

comments.text:
+McJimbo De-Fundy Yeah I kind of figured that'he was right with the 89 part 
though,he probably go 2 and 3 confused..usually a Pontiac has a large 
displacement V-8. Usually Pontiac's V-8s were never smaller than 300 cubic 
inches.

comments.author: RyanTomScott

comments.text:
I had a 59 Bonny Convert with factory leather buckets.I made it a 4 speed 
and did some custom body work and motor mods.The part I find interesting on 
this car is the Lake Pipe caps at the front wheel openings.I did the same 
for my car.When uncapped the blue flames(at nite)would shoot out the sides 
about 6 feet under full throttle.I was just a dumbass kid but that was the 
first love of my life.By the way I loved the gauge cluster especially the 
thin ribbed speedo needle.Artwork in  the USA at it's finest.﻿

comments.author: John Adams

comments.text:
I just came across this video and being a kid who's father bought a used 
one in 1968 for $70 I remember him telling my mom I ran outside and went 
for a ride and fell in love at age 6. Silver Star Chief with a nice 
interior and sparkles in the carpet. The dash was eye candy and I loved the 
styling so much that when dad sold it I balled my eyes out hugging the ass 
end of the car. I was heart broken. You Have great taste, I just ordered a 
SUN STAR 1/18 silver 1959 Bonnie Coupe off EBAY for $100. I would love the 
real thing but living in the north east forget it. I saved this video 
because I love this car and best of all your excitement to see and drive 
it. ﻿

Such a beautiful car, I don't think any, and I mean any cars made from the 
1980's to the present can be called stylish of beautiful. They're cookie 
cutter models, you can't tell an American car from a German car or a 
Japanese car from an Italian , they all come out of the same mixing bowl. 
The 50's, 60's and 70's where exciting times in automotive history with 
their designs and engines. Truly the "good old days"...﻿

comments.author: BuzzyFredrick

comments.text:
Chrysler Corp. should be credited for this Bonneville's design. GM was only 
going to facelift their 1958 designs as was the usual practice since the 
58s were all new.  Rumors were going around about Chrysler's stunning new 
car designs. Some GM stylists went over to Chrysler, saw their stunning new 
designs across the board. Imperial, Chrysler, DeSoto, Dodge and Plymouth 
were all new. They went back to their studio, tore up the face lift 
sketches and started from scatch.﻿
